Posts.Content: Fantastic news Shaz - I've just shuffled along in the paddock and have some carrots waiting for you.  I became a Neddie in April, after my first year mammo - my letter said 'no new abnormalities'.  Needless to say that provided husband with plenty of ammunition.  Love Christine xxx
Posts.Title: NED?

Posts.Content: Hello factseeker, I've just replied to jjtoo and now seen your post. Well, it certainly is interesting that these "benign" and "microcalcifications unlikely to change" are not our experience.  However, 3 years ago when I had the microcalcifications removed by biopsy, I would have been happy to have the annual mammogram, as they were clearly visible on that.  I suppose in my ignorance I did expect microcalcifications to always show on the mammo.  It does make it mighty difficult to swim against the tide of what the medical profession want to do to us, but it is our lives.  I really wish I had insisted on an annual mammo, but I didn't understand the full implication of what microcalcifications could do, but then was told that nothing was likely to happen. AARRGHGHGH.
Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Hello jjtoo, this is my first time posting.  I had stage 2 IDC, 2 areas, ER+, HER-.  Diagnosed from mammogram last March. Have had 2 WLE as DCIS also found, then 3weeks rads and now 5 years anastrozole.  Yes, do think that there should be more done about what I think are red flags.  I'm now 62, but on my first mammogram was recalled as it was unclear, but nothing found.  3 years later on second mammo, microcalcifications found and removed.  "No need to see you for further 3 years - microcalcifications, very unlikely to change into cancer".  Well, yes they bloody do and did!!  This time around IDC and DCIS, so have been lucky to be able to have just the WLE.  I do think further research could be done - sometimes there doesn't seem to be any joined up thinking, when I tried to discuss with the surgeon whether the three years between mammos had allowed it to grow, she just wanted to talk about what was to happen now.  I'm sorry I can't be of much help about your cysts, but I do think you're right that follow up could be vastly improved where anomalies occur.  Wishing you all the best and if there's anything I can help with, please ask.  Sorry for my ranting, but you hit a soft spot!
Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Hello jjtoo, this is my first time posting.  I had stage 2 IDC, 2 areas, ER+, HER-.  Diagnosed from mammogram last March. Have had 2 WLE as DCIS also found, then 3weeks rads and now 5 years anastrozole.  Yes, do think that there should be more done about what I think are red flags.  I'm now 62, but on my first mammogram was recalled as it was unclear, but nothing found.  3 years later on second mammo, microcalcifications found and removed.  "No need to see you for further 3 years - microcalcifications, very unlikely to change into cancer".  Well, yes they bloody do and did!!  This time around IDC and DCIS, so have been lucky to be able to have just the WLE.  I do think further research could be done - sometimes there doesn't seem to be any joined up thinking, when I tried to discuss with the surgeon whether the three years between mammos had allowed it to grow, she just wanted to talk about what was to happen now.  I'm sorry I can't be of much help about your cysts, but I do think you're right that follow up could be vastly improved where anomalies occur.  Wishing you all the best and if there's anything I can help with, please ask.  Sorry for my ranting, but you hit a soft spot!

Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Hello Annie, I didn't have chemo, but have been taking anastrozole now for nearly 2 years.  I didn't use dye from op to rads, but couple of months after rads I dyed my own hair, and have been every 3 months or so since, as I did do before.  Have found that my hair is a lot thinner (boo) and has lost its glossy texture (more boos). I use whatever colour I fancy at the time - usually some sort of auburny brown, no particular make, but without ammonia. Good luck with whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole and hair dye.

Posts.Content: Hello LondonLass, I take anastrozole, which has given me osteoarthritis, and have had constant back and hip pain. Now seeing physiotherapist and doing back exercises and going to a Back Clinic where we were told of the healing properties of SLEEP!  I couldn't sleep due to pain, Doc very good and now I take 10g amitryptiline and I am going to sleep quickly, and not waking up (well, in the morning I do).  This is a complete miracle for me and now feel able to cope with life.  Don't know if this is something that will help at all, but anything is worth a try sometimes.  xxx
Posts.Title: Ideas on coping with backache....

Posts.Content: Not sure if this is of any help, but will put in my sixpennerth!! (Shows how ancient I am.)  Had 2 wle April 2015, now on anastrozole, and yes, the different brands make a huge difference.  Back to last year, really uncomfortable and painful after the ops, with a solid large lump, continually told BCN and onc before I had rads 'oh, nothing to worry about, probably scar tissue'. Had rads, still solid lump. Comes round to April this year and my first mammo, & eventually able to push for an ultrasound, which showed a small seroma.  That was drained and although still got the solid lump (seems smaller), it no longer hurts, can sleep on that side.  I'd always thought a seroma was squidgy/softer/sloshed around, and that a BCN should know the difference between a seroma and scar tissue. Humph!  Good luck anyway and keep pushing for an answer - you know how you feel. xxx
Posts.Title: Breast pain (STILL) 7/8 weeks after RT anyone ?

Posts.Content: I'm still waiting after 8 weeks for my official letter!! Contacted unit after 4 weeks and was told I was ok (now in my 2nd year) and letter will be sent. Tried again last week, yes, letter still on it's way - what by snail post???  I was told that if there had been a problem the unit is phoned immediately and I would have been phoned or letter within the 2 weeks.  I had assumed no news is good news, and still stick to that!! Hope you all hear good news soon as waiting just brings back feelings and memories from diagnosis doesn't it?xxx
Posts.Title: Still waiting for mammogram results

Posts.Content: Hooray AnneCC, welcome to the Neddie paddock.  Is this your first year mammo? I'm now on my second year, but last year I was very emotional about the result.  You're not an idiot, it just means such a lot to have the all clear that it's no wonder some tears are shed. Go on and have a bawl, let it all out!!!  Hope you're doing well. xxx
Posts.Title: Still waiting for mammogram results

Posts.Content: Hoobrayyy, another Neddie.  Brilliant news Snowys Mum - lots of room in the paddock and stacks of carrots to munch (with chocolate middles).
Posts.Title: 1st Annual mammo clear.....I am so happy

Posts.Content: I used a bra extender on my usual bras. I took out the wire on one side of underwired ones - seemed to work ok.  Also just after surgery I got some sports bras, still used extenders, did them up at the front and twizzled them round (M&S).  I did try their after-surgery bras, but couldn't get a comfy fit.  Also after a couple of weeks I got some really soft padded pull on bras (Matalan, v good price) - which have been so comfy I'm still wearing them 3 years on & they still sell them.  Just been to M&S & got my first proper bra which I brought cos it was pretty, but still wanted comfy, from the after-surgery range & got a special £5 off - you don't pay the VAT due to surgery.  Hope you get comfy soon zaf. xxx
Posts.Title: Advice on bras

Posts.Content: Hello Bev - good idea to wait until chemo is over - that is such a tough thing to do that I think just eating what you fancy is the order of the day and be kind to yourself.  Don't worry about your weight either, that will still be there to be dealt with later!!  I can vouch for Slimming World as I have been their Greatest Loser 2 years running - first time last year the week I was diagnosed with bc - what timing.  Don't know whether you're having to do radiotherapy, but that was the only difficulty I had as I didn't have chemo, as they don't like you losing weight then after all the markers have been put in.  The most difficult thing was keeping the weight steady. Ha. Also, if you have hormone tabs like me now, I have found that losing the weight is really much more difficult.  However, am just at my target, having lost 8stone, so pretty happy about that.  Do give SW a go in time, as it really is about healthy eating and not a diet!!  Good luck to you through chemo and beyond. Christine xxx
Posts.Title: Slimming world/ weightwatchers while on Chemo??

Posts.Content: Well George, that takes the biscuit!  I laughed out loud so much and I was only half way through , then got to your punchline and practically wet myself - funniest gag of the year award.  Love your  sense of humour.
Posts.Title: Slimming world/ weightwatchers while on Chemo??

Posts.Content: Ha, great minds think alike Ruby Rose!!
Posts.Title: Advice on bras

Posts.Content: Hello Maggie, I had tremendous trouble getting the Accord brand too, even though, like you, Doc had put it on the prescription. The Doctor's Chemist wouldn't even order it, so went to Boots, who had promised they could get it. But ....  Every time I went into Boots I had to check before I left the shop, only to find it was a DIFFERENT BRAND. Grrr. I was told about making an appointment with the Pharmacist in Boots for a Prescription Check Up, only takes about 5 mins, but I was able to ask for what I wanted and explain why it was necessary.  The previous time I'd been in, the assistant had said 'oh, that costs £65, we can't order that'.  The Pharmacist said he would order it (never mentioned the cost, so I didn't either!), and he said as it had to be specially ordered,  he would order 6 months supply at a time and leave the other packs with my name on.  Good job my hubby was there as well, or I would have kissed him (the pharmacist that is!). Rather annoys me that we have to go through all this palaver, but got there in the end, rather like my wittering on here.  Do hope you can get the Accord brand without any further trouble, just stick to your guns. Arrgh, side effects  - needless to say I've now got osteoarthritis in spine and hands, which I've put down to the anastrozole - even though also taking Adcal D3, which is supposed to help that. Got my second DEXA scan in April, so will see then what damage has been done from 2 years ago. xxx
Posts.Title: Does a change in brand of tamoxifen make any difference please?

Posts.Content: Hello Moonstar, I had my first DEXA scan organised by the oncologist prior to starting Anastrozole ( and I'm Oestrogen Positive ) which was in May 2015 and I was found to be osteopenic and so take Adcal D3.  The second scan was not due until 2 years later, ie May 2017, and I thought my onc would organise that, but as I'm now off the BCN books, shall be asking my doctor if they will organise.  One of those things again where each area seems to do their own thing! At least the DEXA scan is simple and painless! Hope you get on ok.
Posts.Title: Bone density scan, should I have had one?

Posts.Content: Hello Kazash, could have written your letter myself! Been 2 years on anastrozole, now found to have osteoarthritis, particularly bad in spine. Have had second DEXA scan which showed worsening osteopenia (have been taking Adcal D3) and nearly 2" height loss. Took myself to Oncs and now taking bisphosphonates and told to change from anastrozole to either tamoxifen or exemestane. As I'm post menopause decided against tamox and will be taking my first exemestane tomorrow (that is of course if Boots will eventually have it in stock!!).  I've also had tendonitis in thumb, had corticosteroid injection which has sorted that out. I take 20mg amitriptyline at night and now get to sleep, and can get through without waking up with back/leg pain - do need to get up for loo, but able to get back to sleep - something I had not been able to do for months.  Have put EVERYTHING that is now wrong with me down to the anastyzole (even though it could be me now at the great age of 63).  It seems to be the devil or the deep blue sea - even the exemestane give side effects of joint pain. ARRGHGHGH, so does the bifossywhatsits - took my first one Monday (and shush -  managed to sit/stand for 1/2 hour and didn't feel nauseous, or have any other pains, perhaps I shouldn't look at the side effects leaflet, but so far so good). I saw a BCN, even though I'd asked to see the Onc, and BCN had to go rushing off and see Onc for advice, then thrust the tamox & eme leaflets at me, said to make up my mind & ask my doc to prescribe them, no info on the bifossy at all, moan, whinge, and moan again. Still, I'm still here and even though I'm like a crab getting down the stairs in the morning, movement does ease up after a while.  Am doing lots of exercises to improve bone strength and keep muscles moving.  Don't really feel much back pain due to the amittrip - which I find amazing, but it did work.   Oooh, have wittered on far too long. Hope some of it gives you some help.  My doc has been fantastic, always with the belief that 'something can be done about pain', so very grateful to her - she's been more help that BCN!   You should not have to continually suffer pain like that. Do you have a good doc? Hugs to you. Let me know how you get on. xxx
Posts.Title: Changing from anastrozol
